study.title: Increasing Physical Activity Among Sedentary Older Adults:What, Where, When, and With Whom
study.brief_description: The goal of this study is to develop a smart phone app to administer a behavior change program that helps adults to increase daily steps by planning where, when, and with whom to walk. The investigators tested the effectiveness of the walking program app for increasing the number of daily steps among sedentary older adults. The investigators examined the effects on self-efficacy and social integration/support.

front_details.question: Did an app adding scheduling, maps, and social features to encourage walking improve daily steps in sedentary older adults compared to a basic step-counting-and-goal app after one month?
front_details.intervention_fragment: an app adding scheduling, maps, and social features to encourage walking
front_details.intervention_group_fragment: sedentary older adults

study.title: Brain Stimulation and Cognitive Training - Efficacy
study.brief_description:
People with serious mental illness often experience difficulties with thinking skills like memory. These difficulties can make it harder to perform day-to-day activities. The purpose of this study is to test whether combining a type of non-invasive brain stimulation with computerized cognitive exercises is helpful in improving a specific type of memory skill in people who have mental health conditions.

The study is a randomized clinical trial, meaning that participants will be randomly assigned to receive either 'active' or 'inactive' brain stimulation. All participants will complete computerized cognitive exercises, also known as cognitive training.

Overall, participants will be in the study for 6-8 weeks. The study involves 10 visits to the clinic over 2-4 weeks for cognitive training and either active or inactive brain stimulation. Participants will also complete paper-and-pencil assessments at the beginning and end of treatment, and one month after treatment ends.

front_details.question: Did active tDCS + BrainHQ training improve verbal working memory (MCCB letter-number span score) in people getting active tDCS+BrainHQ compared to people getting sham tDCS+BrainHQ after baseline to post-treatment (up to 4 weeks)?
front_details.intervention_fragment: active tDCS + BrainHQ training
front_details.intervention_group_fragment: people getting active tDCS+BrainHQ
front_details.outcome_fragment: verbal working memory (MCCB letter-number span score)

study.title: Timely Nudge About Lab Results to Increase myGeisinger Uptake
study.brief_description: The purpose of the current study is to test whether sending email communications in a timely manner - when patients have laboratory results available to view on the myGeisinger patient portal - increases enrollment in the portal.

front_details.question: Did sending a timely email when lab results are available improve myGeisinger enrollment in patients with a lab result ready to view compared to no email (control) after 1 week?
front_details.intervention_fragment: sending a timely email when lab results are available
front_details.intervention_group_fragment: patients with a lab result ready to view

study.title: Neuropathic Pain After Orchidectomy and Sex Reassignment Surgery
study.brief_description:
Phantom pain is associated with cortical reorganization after amputation. This phenomenon should not play a role in transsexual women, since the cortical representation of the male sex organs is presumably altered. The study investigates the incidence of phantom pain in this patient population.

For this study the following question should be investigated:

Is the incidence of phantom pain and local chronic postsurgical pain lower in sex reassignment surgery from male to female compared to inguinal tumor orchidectomy?

front_details.question: Did orchidectomy (removal of testicles) for testicular cancer improve phantom testis pain in patients who had orchidectomy for cancer compared to trans women who had male-to-female sex reassignment surgery after 6 months to 5 years post-surgery?
front_details.intervention_fragment: orchidectomy (removal of testicles) for testicular cancer
front_details.intervention_group_fragment: patients who had orchidectomy for cancer
front_details.comparator_group_fragment: trans women who had male-to-female sex reassignment surgery

study.title: Motivational Interviewing and Air Cleaners for Smokers With COPD (MOVE COPD)
study.brief_description: COPD is characterized by lung injury and inflammation caused by noxious particles and gases, including those emanating from cigarette smoke and air pollution. Despite the clear detrimental impact of poor air quality on respiratory outcomes, regardless of smoking status, to investigators' knowledge, there are no studied environmental interventions targeting indoor air quality to improve respiratory health of smokers, thus ignoring a potential target for harm reduction. Investigators propose a randomized controlled intervention trial to test whether targeted reductions of multiple indoor pollutants (PM, SHS and NO2) in homes of smokers with COPD will improve respiratory outcomes. Investigators have chosen a potent, multimodal intervention (active air cleaners + Motivational intervention for SHS reduction) in order to maximize the opportunity to prove that there is a health benefit to active smokers with COPD from indoor air pollution reduction.

front_details.question: Did HEPA air cleaners + phone motivational interviewing for a home smoking ban improve respiratory quality of life (St. George's Respiratory Questionnaire) in smokers with COPD who continued smoking compared to sham air cleaners with smoking cessation counseling only after 6 months?
front_details.intervention_fragment: HEPA air cleaners + phone motivational interviewing for a home smoking ban
front_details.intervention_group_fragment: smokers with COPD who continued smoking
front_details.outcome_fragment: respiratory quality of life (St. George's Respiratory Questionnaire)
front_details.comparator_group_fragment: sham air cleaners with smoking cessation counseling only

study.title: Engaging Patients in Colon Cancer Screening Decisions During COVID-19
study.brief_description: The goal of the study is to examine whether a shared decision making intervention improves decision making about colon cancer screening for patients who had their colonoscopy delayed or postponed due to the COVID pandemic. Eligible patients (n=800) will be randomly assigned to either the intervention or control arm. A subset will be surveyed about 6-8 weeks post intervention to measure shared decision making, their intention to follow through with screening, and their decisional conflict. Study staff will conduct medical chart review to track receipt of colon cancer screening within 6 months. The statistician will test whether patients in the intervention arm report more shared decision making, less decisional conflict, higher intention to follow through on screening and have higher screening rates compared to those in the control arm.

front_details.question: Did mailed shared decision-making sheet and decision coaching improve shared decision-making about colon cancer screening (SDM score) in patients with colonoscopy delayed due to COVID-19 compared to usual care (scheduling calls/texts) after about 8 weeks?
front_details.intervention_fragment: mailed shared decision-making sheet and decision coaching
front_details.intervention_group_fragment: patients with colonoscopy delayed due to COVID-19
front_details.outcome_fragment: shared decision-making about colon cancer screening (SDM score)

study.title: Behavior Enhances Drug Reduction of Incontinence (BE-DRI)
study.brief_description: The primary aim of this study is to test if the addition of behavioral treatment to drug therapy for the treatment of urge incontinence will increase the number of patients who can discontinue drug therapy and sustain a significant reduction of incontinence.

front_details.question: Did drug plus behavioral training improve success (off meds/other therapies and ≥70% fewer leakage episodes) in women with urge urinary incontinence compared to drug alone after 8 months?
front_details.intervention_fragment: drug plus behavioral training
front_details.intervention_group_fragment: women with urge urinary incontinence
front_details.outcome_fragment: success (off meds/other therapies and ≥70% fewer leakage episodes)

study.title: Listening Visits for Emotionally Distressed Mothers of Hospitalized Newborns
study.brief_description: The proposed research has potential to dramatically improve care for emotionally distressed mothers of newborns hospitalized on the neonatal intensive care unit (NICU). Clinical NICU nurses are well-positioned to provide emotional support in the form of Listening Visits. Specifically, these nurses are easily accessible to NICU mothers, are often the most trusted professional on the healthcare team, they are knowledgeable about the newborn's medical conditions, and, finally they are already skilled in the art of warm communication. This intervention should not only improve depressive outcomes in emotionally distressed NICU mothers but also indirectly impact maternal perception of nurse support which is in turn related to depression symptoms and patient satisfaction, as well as infant length of stay by accelerating maternal readiness for infant discharge.

front_details.question: Did in-person nurse-led Listening Visits improve depressive symptoms (IDAS-GD score) in emotionally distressed NICU mothers compared to usual social-worker care after 4 and 8 weeks?
front_details.intervention_fragment: in-person nurse-led Listening Visits
front_details.intervention_group_fragment: emotionally distressed NICU mothers

study.title: Lottery Incentive Nudges to Increase Influenza Vaccinations
study.brief_description: In the current study, the study team will explore whether small incentives are effective at promoting flu vaccine uptake. The study is designed to compare the relative efficacy of incentives of equal perceived expected value (EV) or equal implementation costs, to assess whether people are more likely to get vaccinated in response to lotteries with very high payoffs than to small certain cash payout or slightly higher-probability, more moderate payoffs. In particular, given the potential appeal of official state lottery tickets, one study arm will receive a Pennsylvania scratch-off lottery ticket for getting a flu vaccine. A primary hypothesis is that lotteries will outperform simple reminders (encouraging respondents to get the flu shot at their upcoming appointment) and the standard of care, representing the ambient healthcare system and public health campaigns to increase vaccination.

front_details.question: Did a $1 PA scratch-off lottery ticket for getting a flu shot improve getting a flu shot at their appointment in Geisinger patients 18+ with an upcoming PCP or specialist appointment during the 2021–22 flu season compared to $1 cash for getting a flu shot after 3 days after randomization?
front_details.intervention_fragment: a $1 PA scratch-off lottery ticket for getting a flu shot
front_details.intervention_group_fragment: Geisinger patients 18+ with an upcoming PCP or specialist appointment during the 2021–22 flu season
front_details.outcome_fragment: getting a flu shot at their appointment
front_details.comparator_group_fragment: $1 cash for getting a flu shot

study.title: Pilot of Lifestyle and Asthma Intervention
study.brief_description:
This is to pilot test a weight loss intervention in obese patients with poorly controlled asthma.

Obesity is a risk factor for the development of asthma (approximately 250,000 cases per year of asthma in the U.S. are related to obesity).

Investigators' ultimate purpose is to test the hypothesis that weight loss through an intensive life style intervention will improve asthma control. But investigators first need to establish whether the weight loss intervention is effective in patients with asthma.

Objectives

1. The primary objective of this study is to determine the effectiveness of an internet-based weight loss intervention in producing weight loss in obese patients with poorly controlled asthma.
2. The ultimate purpose is to implement a multi-center weight loss intervention trial for obese patients with poorly controlled asthma.

front_details.question: Did an online weight-loss program (reduced calories + increased activity, weekly group chats) improve the percent achieving ≥5% weight loss in adults with asthma compared to Control after 6 months?
front_details.intervention_fragment: an online weight-loss program (reduced calories + increased activity, weekly group chats)
front_details.intervention_group_fragment: adults with asthma

study.title: The Effect of Different Exercise Types on Migraine Frequency in Individuals With Migraine
study.brief_description: The purpose of this study is to evaluate and compare the effect of different exercise types and combinations on migraine attacks in patients with migraine.

front_details.question: Did combined aerobic + resistance exercise improve number of migraine days per month in people with migraine compared to an unknown comparator after 12 and 20 weeks?
front_details.intervention_fragment: combined aerobic + resistance exercise
front_details.intervention_group_fragment: people with migraine
front_details.outcome_fragment: number of migraine days per month

study.title: Improving Employment and Reducing Recidivism Among Prison Offenders Via Virtual Interview Training Tool (MICHR)
study.brief_description:
The goal is to conduct a feasibility effectiveness RCT of Virtual Interview Training (VIT) by comparing employment and recidivism outcomes of offenders (25 years and older) receiving vocational services as usual (SAU) plus VIT (SAU+VIT) with the outcomes of offenders receiving only services as usual (SAU-only).

The plan calls for participants to include offenders who are at moderate to high risk for reoffending (with an emphasis on violent-crime reoffending) who are currently enrolled in a Vocational Village Prison Setting with the Michigan Department of Corrections.

front_details.question: Did adding virtual job interview practice and coaching (VR-JIT) improve getting a job (employment rate by self-report) in prison offenders in the Vocational Village program compared to usual Vocational Village services after 6 and 12 months post-release?
front_details.intervention_fragment: adding virtual job interview practice and coaching (VR-JIT)
front_details.intervention_group_fragment: prison offenders in the Vocational Village program
front_details.outcome_fragment: getting a job (employment rate by self-report)

study.title: Dismantling the Components and Dosing of CBT for Co-Occurring Disorders
study.brief_description: The purpose of this study is to establish a brief CBT intervention that can largely, if not fully eliminate the deleterious effect of common co-occurring anxiety disorders on alcohol use disorder treatment outcomes.

front_details.question: Did 6 CBT sessions to de-couple anxiety and drinking improve number who relapsed to drinking in the de-coupling group compared to the anxiety-reduction group after 4 months?
front_details.intervention_fragment: 6 CBT sessions to de-couple anxiety and drinking
front_details.intervention_group_fragment: the de-coupling group

study.title: Skin Self-Examination Education During Mammography
study.brief_description: The skin self-examination for melanoma (SSE) educational materials were developed with the input provided by women undergoing screening mammograms. The investigators seek to evaluate the performance of SSE by women and find out if women seek care with a dermatologist for a concerning mole or for a melanoma screening examination by a dermatologist after reviewing the materials received during the mammogram visit. The purpose of this study is to enhance the early detection of melanoma among women who are engaging in health promotion by having mammograms. The investigators specifically aim to evaluate the performance of SSE by women, who receive information during their mammogram appointment, and then follow-up with dermatology for a melanoma screening examination.

front_details.question: Did adding a 1-week reminder call/email plus an educational poster and brochure about skin self-exams improve performing a skin self-examination in women who received poster, brochure and a 1-week reminder compared to women who received a brochure only after 3 months?
front_details.intervention_fragment: adding a 1-week reminder call/email plus an educational poster and brochure about skin self-exams
front_details.intervention_group_fragment: women who received poster, brochure and a 1-week reminder
front_details.comparator_group_fragment: women who received a brochure only

study.title: Olfactory Contributions to Sleep-dependent Food Craving
study.brief_description: This within-subject experiment uses one night of acute sleep restriction (4h) vs normal sleep (8h) to study state-dependent changes in olfactory processing. Odor-evoked blood oxygen level dependent (BOLD) responses will be measured in olfactory brain regions using functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI). Food intake will be measured at a buffet.

front_details.question: Did 4-h sleep (sleep deprivation) improve piriform cortex decoding of food vs non-food odors (fMRI accuracy) in healthy normal-weight adults compared to 8-h sleep (normal sleep) after the evening (~7pm) following the manipulated night?
front_details.intervention_fragment: 4-h sleep (sleep deprivation)
front_details.intervention_group_fragment: healthy normal-weight adults
front_details.outcome_fragment: piriform cortex decoding of food vs non-food odors (fMRI accuracy)
front_details.timeframe_fragment: the evening (~7pm) following the manipulated night

study.title: Behavioral & Nutritional Treatment to Help CF Preschoolers Grow
study.brief_description: The primary objective of this NIH funded clinical trial is to conduct a multi-center, randomized, controlled trial comparing two interventions: a behavioral plus nutrition intervention to a nutrition intervention. This study will (a) determine the impact of the behavioral intervention on energy intake and weight gain; (b) examine the durability of the behavioral intervention's impact on growth (weight and height) one year following treatment; and (c) explore the relation between physical activity and growth.

front_details.question: Did behavioral plus nutrition counseling to increase calorie intake improve energy intake (kcal/day) in preschoolers with cystic fibrosis compared to education/attention control after 6 months?
front_details.intervention_fragment: behavioral plus nutrition counseling to increase calorie intake
front_details.intervention_group_fragment: preschoolers with cystic fibrosis

study.title: Digital Literacy Promotion
study.brief_description: This study evaluates the effects of digital versus standard literacy promotion, as well as dialogic language behaviors and reading comprehension among infants when comparing the use of e-books to standard board books. Around half of the participants will receive standard board books at the 6, 9, and 12 month well visits, while the other half will receive digital e-books.

front_details.question: Did using e-books improve infant development (Bayley-3 composite scores) in parent-infant dyads given e-books compared to parent-infant dyads given board books after about 1 month post 12-month visit?
front_details.intervention_fragment: using e-books
front_details.intervention_group_fragment: parent-infant dyads given e-books

study.title: Evaluation of an Internet-based Intervention for Hazardous Drinkers
study.brief_description: The purpose of this study is to determine whether the investigators internet-based intervention is effective to help hazardous drinkers reducing their alcohol consumption.

front_details.question: Did an interactive web program to reduce drinking improve weekly alcohol intake (lower = better) in hazardous drinkers compared to minimal information (info + alcohol diary) after 6 weeks?
front_details.intervention_fragment: an interactive web program to reduce drinking
front_details.intervention_group_fragment: hazardous drinkers

study.title: Justice-Involved Veterans and Moral Reconation Therapy
study.brief_description: The purpose of this study is to determine whether Moral Reconation Therapy (MRT) is effective for reducing risk of criminal recidivism and improving other health-related outcomes (substance use, mental health, housing, and employment problems) among justice-involved Veterans entering residential mental health treatment programs in the Department of Veterans Affairs (VA).

front_details.question: Did group therapy to reduce antisocial thinking (MRT) improve criminal thinking (risk for reoffending) in justice-involved Veterans in VA residential care compared to usual VA residential care after 6 months?
front_details.intervention_fragment: group therapy to reduce antisocial thinking (MRT)
front_details.intervention_group_fragment: justice-involved Veterans in VA residential care

study.title: Enhancing Indoor, Community, and Advanced Wheelchair Skills in Spinal Cord Injury (SCI)
study.brief_description: We propose to test an evidence-based wheelchair skills training program to optimize wheelchair safety and performance in veterans with SCI. The proposed training program incorporates emerging evidence on wheelchair biomechanics and motor-skills learning, and addresses recommendations in a new clinical practice guideline. Given the difficulty in translating wheelchair skills learned in a therapy clinic with "real world" problems in the home and community post-discharge, we are proposing to conduct the wheelchair skills training in and around the veteran's home. The immediate goal is to enhance ability, performance time, safety, community participation, and quality of life, while minimizing physical strain. The ultimate goal is to reduce morbidity/mortality associated with wheelchair use and promote successful aging with a disability.

front_details.question: Did five weeks of wheelchair skills training improve wheelchair skills (WST total score) in people with spinal cord injury (SCI) compared to basic health education after 1 year?
front_details.intervention_fragment: five weeks of wheelchair skills training
front_details.intervention_group_fragment: people with spinal cord injury (SCI)

study.title: Comparison of E-health vs. In-person Multi-Family Group (MFG)
study.brief_description: As specified in the VA Uniform Services Handbook, Family Psycho-Education (FPE) treatment must be available to all Veterans with schizophrenia who could benefit, and their family members. This includes those receiving care at Community Based Outpatient Clinics (CBOCs), and at Psychosocial Rehabilitation and Recovery Centers (PRRCs), whether provided on site, by referral, or by telemental health. However, less than 5% of VA medical centers offer FPE. Clearly, a major challenge is to devise ways to deliver mental health treatments and services to Veterans who need them in ways that meet their needs and preferences. The proposed project will compare the use of a website to deliver FPE to that of in-person delivered FPE. The findings could have profound implications for the VA's ability to improve the reach, use, appeal, and effectiveness of FPE for Veterans with schizophrenia, by using an e-health model that facilitates family involvement.

front_details.question: Did online multi-family psychoeducation (web-based FPE) improve personal goal attainment (Goal Attainment Scale) in Veterans with schizophrenia and their family members compared to in-person MFG (multi-family group psychoeducation) after 3, 6, and 12 months?
front_details.intervention_fragment: online multi-family psychoeducation (web-based FPE)
front_details.intervention_group_fragment: Veterans with schizophrenia and their family members

study.title: BestFIT: a Personalized Weight Loss Program
study.brief_description:
The purpose of this study is to learn how to personalize weight loss programs. In this research we will study:

1. Whether a weight loss counselor should decide if the traditional weight loss therapy is working either after 3 or 7 weekly sessions of therapy and
2. For those who haven't lost the expected amount of weight, whether it is more effective to add packaged meals to the traditional weight loss therapy or to change to an enhanced version of behavioral weight loss therapy.

front_details.question: Did adding portion-controlled meals (pre-prepared reduced-calorie meals) improve weight loss (weight change from baseline) in suboptimal responders to behavioral weight loss therapy compared to switching to acceptance-based behavioral therapy after 6 and 18 months after baseline?
front_details.intervention_fragment: adding portion-controlled meals (pre-prepared reduced-calorie meals)
front_details.intervention_group_fragment: suboptimal responders to behavioral weight loss therapy

study.title: Lung Cancer Screening Navigation for Homeless People
study.brief_description:
The investigators will conduct a pragmatic clinical trial to test the effect of patient navigation on lung cancer screening (LCS) low-dose computed tomography (LDCT) completion among Boston Health Care for the Homeless Program (BHCHP) patients at increased risk for lung cancer. Patient navigation is a strategy for guiding individuals through complex health systems, and the investigators hypothesize that this may be a promising approach for helping homeless-experienced people overcome their unique barriers to obtaining LCS.

The investigators will aim to recruit 300 people to participate in this research study; 100 will be randomly assigned to arm 1 (usual care) and 200 will be randomly assigned to arm 2 (patient navigation). Randomization of participants will be stratified by smoking status, housing status, clinical site, and whether they have previously discussed LCS with their primary care provider (PCP) to ensure balance between study groups on these variables. People assigned to the usual care arm will be referred back to their PCP for further management. People assigned to the patient navigation arm will be given the chance to work with a LCS navigator. The navigator will assist participants and their PCPs with all aspects of the LCS process in addition to offering brief tobacco counseling for current smokers.

The primary aim of the trial is to determine-among homeless-experienced people who are eligible for LCS-the effect of patient navigation on 1) LCS LDCT completion at 6 months post-enrollment and 2) LCS LDCT completion at 6 months with diagnostic follow-up of abnormal results within 1 month of the recommended time frame. Study outcomes will be assessed by examining participant health records.

Following the intervention, qualitative interviews will be conducted with 40 participants and 10 BHCHP PCPs to better understand how the LCS process unfolds in the setting of homelessness, the ways in which the navigator facilitated this process, and opportunities for improving the navigation intervention for future use.

front_details.question: Did patient navigation to complete LDCT lung cancer screening improve getting a low-dose CT (LDCT) for lung cancer screening in homeless people with patient navigation compared to homeless people with usual care without navigation after 6 months (26 weeks)?
front_details.intervention_fragment: patient navigation to complete LDCT lung cancer screening
front_details.intervention_group_fragment: homeless people with patient navigation
front_details.outcome_fragment: getting a low-dose CT (LDCT) for lung cancer screening
front_details.comparator_group_fragment: homeless people with usual care without navigation

study.title: The Effectiveness of a Decision-Support Tool for Adult Consumers With Mental Health Needs and Their Care Managers
study.brief_description: The primary goal of the proposed study is to investigate the implementation and effectiveness of the mPOWR (Moving Patient-centered Outcomes through Wellness and Recovery) in diverse urban and rural community mental health settings. The study compares patient participation and outcomes using the mPOWR system to a usual care control condition. Four community mental health agencies participate in the research: two in San Francisco (urban) and two in N.M. (rural). One site in each setting serves as the mPOWR implementation site and the other serves as the control site. Service sites were randomly assigned to intervention or usual care conditions. A quasi experimental design was used; only eligible participants were enrolled in the study (e.g., exclusion criteria of moderate to severe cognitive impairment, patient services structured for provision of mPOWR implementation, etc.). The study design will employ repeated quantitative measures to assess change in outcomes within and across conditions over time. Qualitative methods in the form of focus group interviews will also be used to round out the information obtained about patient and provider expectations and experiences. Primary outcomes of interest include: Short Form Health Survey-12 (SF-12; physical and mental health aspects of health and well-being); Outcome Rating Scale (ORS; general well-being, personal well-being, close relationships, and work/school/friend relationships); Shared Decision Making Questionnaire (congruence of patient's and provider's participation in therapeutic decision making and patient's understanding of treatment and treatment options); Working Alliance Inventory (perception of therapeutic alliance); and Satisfaction Questionnaire (communication patterns between physicians and their patients).

front_details.question: Did a patient-centered decision-support tool and shared decision-making (SDM) toolkit improve physical health (SF-12 physical component score) in adults at the urban site whose case managers used the tool compared to adults at a similar site receiving usual care after 24 months?
front_details.intervention_fragment: a patient-centered decision-support tool and shared decision-making (SDM) toolkit
front_details.intervention_group_fragment: adults at the urban site whose case managers used the tool
front_details.comparator_group_fragment: adults at a similar site receiving usual care

study.title: Using Technology-Assisted Stepped Care Intervention to Improve Adherence in Adolescents With Asthma
study.brief_description: To test the preliminary efficacy of the TASC adherence promotion intervention for adolescents with asthma in a feasibility randomized controlled trial compared to treatment as usual control arm.

front_details.question: Did a tech-assisted stepped-care program (education, tailored text reminders, and telehealth problem-solving) improve inhaler adherence (percent change via electronic monitoring) in adolescents (12–18) with moderate to severe persistent asthma compared to treatment as usual (no extra intervention) after 30 days?
front_details.intervention_fragment: a tech-assisted stepped-care program (education, tailored text reminders, and telehealth problem-solving)
front_details.intervention_group_fragment: adolescents (12–18) with moderate to severe persistent asthma
front_details.outcome_fragment: inhaler adherence (percent change via electronic monitoring)

study.title: Visual Stimulation for Pain Relief
study.brief_description: The goal of this study is to investigate a novel neuromodulatory approach utilizing visual stimulation to impact pain perception in healthy participants.

front_details.question: Did viewing AI-guided visual stimuli on a screen improve pain (VAS score) in healthy controls compared to control after up to 2 hours?
front_details.intervention_fragment: viewing AI-guided visual stimuli on a screen
front_details.intervention_group_fragment: healthy controls

study.title: Lay Health Worker Engage, Educate, and Encourage Patients to Share
study.brief_description: The purpose of the LEAPS program is to understand how a trained lay health worker who engages with newly diagnosed patients after a diagnosis of an advanced stage of cancer can help to engage patients in advance care planning, improve patient satisfaction with their decision-making, activation, quality of life, and healthcare resource utilization.

front_details.question: Did lay health worker coaching about goals of care improve quality of life (Functional Assessment of Cancer Therapy—General, FACT-G) in people with cancer compared to usual care after 4 months (change from baseline)?
front_details.intervention_fragment: lay health worker coaching about goals of care
front_details.intervention_group_fragment: people with cancer
front_details.outcome_fragment: quality of life (Functional Assessment of Cancer Therapy—General, FACT-G)

study.title: Investigating Fear Of Recurrence as a Modifiable Mechanism of Behavior Change
study.brief_description: The primary goal of this project is to identify, measure, and influence fear of cardiac event recurrence, a candidate mechanism of change in medication adherence in patients with suspected acute coronary syndrome (ACS). An intervention will be tested that has been used to reduce fear of cancer recurrence by changing emotion-related patterns of attention allocation and interpretation of neutral stimuli. Secondarily, the study will test whether a reduction in fear of cardiac event recurrence improves medication adherence.

front_details.question: Did tablet-based attention & interpretation training improve fear of recurrence (Concerns About Recurrence total score) in ACS patients with early PTSD symptoms (CBMT group) compared to attention-control tablet training (placebo) after about 4 weeks (pre- to post-training)?
front_details.intervention_fragment: tablet-based attention & interpretation training
front_details.intervention_group_fragment: ACS patients with early PTSD symptoms (CBMT group)
front_details.outcome_fragment: fear of recurrence (Concerns About Recurrence total score)

study.title: Adaptive Disclosure: A Combat-Specific PTSD Treatment
study.brief_description: The primary objective of this randomized controlled non-inferiority trial is to determine whether or not Adaptive Disclosure (AD), a new combat-specific psychotherapy for Post Traumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD), is as least as effective as Cognitive Processing Therapy, cognitive only version (CPT-C), in terms of its impact on deployment-related psychological health problems (specifically PTSD and depression) and functioning.

front_details.question: Did 12 sessions of Cognitive Processing Therapy (CPT-C) improve PTSD status (clinician-rated recovery/improvement on CAPS-IV) in Marines with combat-related PTSD compared to 8 sessions of imaginal exposure plus cognitive/experiential therapy after post-treatment (8-12 weeks)?
front_details.intervention_fragment: 12 sessions of Cognitive Processing Therapy (CPT-C)
front_details.intervention_group_fragment: Marines with combat-related PTSD
front_details.comparator_group_fragment: 8 sessions of imaginal exposure plus cognitive/experiential therapy

study.title: Technological Platforms and Telerehabilitation in Heart Surgery
study.brief_description: In this randomised, double-blind, pilot study, the investigators aim to assess whether a telerehabilitation strategy could improve outcomes among patients with recent heart surgery. Included participants will receive a comprehensive rehabilitation programme comprised of physical therapy, nutritional counselling, psychological assistance in addition to standard medical care. After 12 sessions of physical therapy, patients will be randomised to receive telerehabilitation with a portable EKG device and a smartphone application or usual care. The primary endpoint for this study is the exercise capacity of included participants, which will be assessed using an ergospirometer at 4 and 8 weeks after randomisation.

front_details.question: Did telerehabilitation (portable ECG + smartphone app) improve exercise capacity (peak oxygen uptake — VO2 peak) in post–heart-surgery patients compared to routine care (standard rehab) after 4 weeks after randomisation?
front_details.intervention_fragment: telerehabilitation (portable ECG + smartphone app)
front_details.intervention_group_fragment: post–heart-surgery patients
front_details.outcome_fragment: exercise capacity (peak oxygen uptake — VO2 peak)

study.title: Study of Medical Student Use of Templates to Document Outpatient Asthma Care in Electronic Medical Record
study.brief_description: The purpose of the study is to measure the effectiveness of a social marketing-based medical education intervention on student use of evidence-based templates for documenting outpatient asthma care within an electronic medical record.

front_details.question: Did a doctor-led workshop using 7 social-marketing persuasion messages to encourage using an evidence-based asthma EMR template improve use of the evidence-based Asthma AIM EMR template to document outpatient mild persistent asthma in medical students exposed to the persuasion-embedded documentation workshop compared to medical students exposed to the same workshop without the 7 persuasion messages after immediately after and about 35 days later?
front_details.intervention_fragment: a doctor-led workshop using 7 social-marketing persuasion messages to encourage using an evidence-based asthma EMR template
front_details.intervention_group_fragment: medical students exposed to the persuasion-embedded documentation workshop
front_details.outcome_fragment: use of the evidence-based Asthma AIM EMR template to document outpatient mild persistent asthma
front_details.comparator_group_fragment: medical students exposed to the same workshop without the 7 persuasion messages
front_details.timeframe_fragment: immediately after and about 35 days later

study.title: Promoting Informed Decisions About Cancer Screening in Older Adults
study.brief_description: This project aims to examine the impact of different interventions designed to help individualize colorectal cancer (CRC) screening decisions in adults aged 76-85. Clinicians will be assigned by chance to one of two arms. In the Intervention arm, clinician participants will complete a training course and will also be notified of patients in the target age group who are due for a discussion about CRC screening. In the Comparator arm, clinician participants will be notified of their patients in the target age group with an upcoming visit who are due for a discussion about CRC screening. The investigators expect that patients seen by clinicians in the intervention arm will report more involvement in the decision making process, be more knowledgeable about the risks and benefits of CRC screening, and will have better quality decisions. Further, the investigators expect that the physicians in the intervention arm will have greater confidence in and demonstrate more skills for conducting shared decision making conversations as compared to those in the control arm.

front_details.question: Did training clinicians in shared decision-making (plus notification) improve shared decision making (SDMP score) in patients (age 76–85) of clinicians who received training and notification compared to patients (age 76–85) of clinicians who received notification only after about 1 week after the visit?
front_details.intervention_fragment: training clinicians in shared decision-making (plus notification)
front_details.intervention_group_fragment: patients (age 76–85) of clinicians who received training and notification
front_details.comparator_group_fragment: patients (age 76–85) of clinicians who received notification only

study.title: Environmental Design for Behavioral Regulation in People With Dementia
study.brief_description: Individuals with dementia present with changes in behaviors throughout the continuum of cognitive decline. Environmental features may be influential in behavioral regulation. The purpose of this study is to assess the feasibility of environmental design protocols in older adults with dementia and their caregivers. Thirty subjects with moderate to severe Alzheimer's disease as primary dementia type, and their caregivers, will be randomly assigned to one of three arms: standard care; standard environmental design protocol; or personalized environmental design protocol.

front_details.question: Did individualized home environment changes with a personalized sensory kit improve protocol adherence (percent with ≥75% adherence) in Alzheimer's patients and caregivers compared to standard environmental design (non-personalized kit + caregiver training) after 6 weeks?
front_details.intervention_fragment: individualized home environment changes with a personalized sensory kit
front_details.intervention_group_fragment: Alzheimer's patients and caregivers
front_details.comparator_group_fragment: standard environmental design (non-personalized kit + caregiver training)

study.title: Audit-and-feedback to Improve Antimicrobial-prescribing Among Urologists
study.brief_description:
Antimicrobial resistance is one of today''s most urgent public health problems. An important strategy to slow the spread of antimicrobial resistance is the promotion of judicious antimicrobial use. There are many opportunities to reduce unnecessary antimicrobial-prescribing, including in patients undergoing surgical procedures. The following study will specifically study opportunities to improve antimicrobial use in patients undergoing common urologic procedures at hospitals in the Veterans Health Administration (VHA).

Guidelines recommend giving antibiotics for no more than 24-hours after most urologic procedures, but the investigators have shown that the unnecessary use of post-procedural antimicrobials is common in this setting. In a national cohort of nearly 30,000 VHA patients, excessive post-procedural antimicrobials were prescribed after 37.2% of urologic procedures for a median duration of 3.0 excess days.

In this study, the investigators will evaluate whether giving regular feedback to providers at 3 VHA hospitals can reduce unnecessary antimicrobial use after urologic procedures.

front_details.question: Did regular feedback to urologists about excessive post-op antibiotic use improve excessive post-procedural antibiotic use (prescription on day 1) in patients undergoing TURP, TUBRT, or URS at 3 VHA hospitals compared to the same hospitals during the 2-year baseline after 12 months?
front_details.intervention_fragment: regular feedback to urologists about excessive post-op antibiotic use
front_details.intervention_group_fragment: patients undergoing TURP, TUBRT, or URS at 3 VHA hospitals
front_details.outcome_fragment: excessive post-procedural antibiotic use (prescription on day 1)
front_details.comparator_group_fragment: the same hospitals during the 2-year baseline

study.title: Improving ADHD Teen Driving
study.brief_description: Teens with Attention-Deficit/Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD) have high rates of negative driving outcomes, including motor vehicle crashes, which may be caused by visual inattention (i.e., looking away from the roadway to perform secondary tasks). A driving intervention that trains teens to reduce instances of looking away from the roadway will be tested in teens with ADHD.

front_details.question: Did computer+simulator training with real-time auditory feedback to curb long glances from the road improve count of long (≥2 s) glances away from the road during a driving simulator in teens with ADHD who received the glance-feedback training compared to teens with ADHD who received rules-of-the-road training (no gaze feedback) after 1 month post-training?
front_details.intervention_fragment: computer+simulator training with real-time auditory feedback to curb long glances from the road
front_details.intervention_group_fragment: teens with ADHD who received the glance-feedback training
front_details.outcome_fragment: count of long (≥2 s) glances away from the road during a driving simulator
front_details.comparator_group_fragment: teens with ADHD who received rules-of-the-road training (no gaze feedback)

study.title: Weight Discrimination and Poor Cardiovascular Health
study.brief_description:
People with obesity regularly experience discrimination on the basis of their body weight and such experiences are associated with increased risk for poor cardiovascular health. The goal of this clinical trial is to identify cognitive, affective, behavioral, and physiological factors that explain the relationship between weight discrimination and poor health outcomes.

A diverse sample of adults with obesity will be randomly assigned to a social interaction encounter that simulates a typical weight discrimination experience (experimental manipulation) vs. a control manipulation that does not involve discrimination. The investigators will examine the immediate effects of the experimental manipulation on cognitive (e.g., self-regulation), affective (e.g., negative emotion), behavioral (e.g., comfort eating), and physiological (e.g., cortisol secretion) outcomes.

Two additional aims of the study are to identify psychological traits that moderate responses to weight discrimination and to assess whether the negative health effects of weight discrimination differ by age, sex/gender, race, or ethnicity.

front_details.question: Did experiencing weight discrimination improve negative affect (negative emotions; PANAS-X score) in adults with obesity compared to control experience after 2 minutes?
front_details.intervention_fragment: experiencing weight discrimination
front_details.intervention_group_fragment: adults with obesity

study.title: Addressing Palliative Care Needs Among Intensive Care Unit Family Members
study.brief_description: The quality of palliative care is highly variable for many patients treated in intensive care units (ICUs) and their family members. To address these challenges, the investigators will test the impact of a mobile app designed to help families navigate ICU-based palliative care vs. usual care. The investigators hypothesize that the intervention will reduce patient/family member unmet palliative care needs and improve the quality of clinical-family communication in racially/ethnically diverse populations.

front_details.question: Did a needs-focused mobile app for families and ICU clinicians improve unmet palliative care needs (NEST score) in ICU family members given the app compared to usual ICU care after about 3 days post-randomization?
front_details.intervention_fragment: a needs-focused mobile app for families and ICU clinicians
front_details.intervention_group_fragment: ICU family members given the app

study.title: Wellness Self-Management
study.brief_description: Veterans with schizophrenia, other serious mental illnesses (SMI), and Post Traumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD) are at elevated risk for co-occurring chronic medical conditions resulting in increased risk of disability, high health care spending, reduced quality of life and early mortality. Physical wellness is increasingly recognized as a key component of the VA's commitment to developing recovery-oriented and Veteran-centered mental health treatment. There is also growing recognition of the value of interventions that promote and improve patient self-management of chronic medical conditions. Building on the established efficacy of consumer facilitated medical illness self-management programming used in the general population and two recent adaptations for use with SMI adults in the public health sector (including the investigators' own evaluation of an intervention called Living Well), the investigators propose to complete a randomized controlled effectiveness trial of the Living Well intervention and simultaneously conduct a well specified process evaluation to optimize knowledge accrual regarding important factors that may improve future adoption, implementation and sustainability of the Living Well intervention in the VA system of care.

front_details.question: Did peer co-led 12-session self-management group for veterans' physical health improve general health functioning (SF-12 score) in veterans with serious mental illness and at least one chronic medical condition compared to a medical illness education and support group after 3 months (post-intervention)?
front_details.intervention_fragment: peer co-led 12-session self-management group for veterans' physical health
front_details.intervention_group_fragment: veterans with serious mental illness and at least one chronic medical condition
front_details.comparator_group_fragment: a medical illness education and support group

study.title: Evaluation of Treatments to Improve Smoking Cessation Medication Adherence
study.brief_description: Many smokers fail to take their smoking cessation medication as recommended. This research is designed to identify treatments that improve the use of cessation medications and to determine whether an increase in medication use results in increased cessation success. This research will also identify treatments that help people stay quit after a quit attempt and will pioneer more efficient research methods.

front_details.question: Did 26 weeks of nicotine patch + gum improve 7-day abstinence (not smoking in past 7 days; self-reported 7-day point-prevalence abstinence) in smokers given 26 weeks of patch + gum compared to smokers given 8 weeks of patch + gum after 52 weeks?
front_details.intervention_fragment: 26 weeks of nicotine patch + gum
front_details.intervention_group_fragment: smokers given 26 weeks of patch + gum
front_details.outcome_fragment: 7-day abstinence (not smoking in past 7 days; self-reported 7-day point-prevalence abstinence)
front_details.comparator_group_fragment: smokers given 8 weeks of patch + gum

study.title: Expressing Personal Recollections in English or Spanish to Alleviate Traumatic Emotions (Exprésate)
study.brief_description: The purpose of this study is to test if expressive writing about traumatic events has positive changes in women living with post-traumatic stress.

front_details.question: Did writing about traumatic experiences in English improve PTSD symptoms (Impact of Event Scale score) in people writing in English about trauma compared to people writing in Spanish about the previous day without emotions after 6 weeks?
front_details.intervention_fragment: writing about traumatic experiences in English
front_details.intervention_group_fragment: people writing in English about trauma
front_details.outcome_fragment: PTSD symptoms (Impact of Event Scale score)
front_details.comparator_group_fragment: people writing in Spanish about the previous day without emotions

study.title: The FAITH! Trial: A mHealth Intervention to Improve Cardiovascular Health Among African-Americans
study.brief_description: The purpose of this project is to apply a community-based participatory research (CBPR) approach to rigorously refine and test the feasibility and preliminary efficacy of an existing cardiovascular (CV) health and wellness digital application (app) prototype to improve CV health according to the American Heart Association Life's Simple 7 (LS7) framework among African-American (AA) adults within faith communities. The investigators hypothesize that the app-based intervention will be feasible and improve LS7 among AAs from baseline to 6-months post-intervention.

front_details.question: Did using a 10-week tailored smartphone app (education, self-monitoring, quizzes, messages, social support) improve Life's Simple 7 score (overall heart health) in African-American adults compared to a delayed-intervention control (no app during control period) after 6 months?
front_details.intervention_fragment: using a 10-week tailored smartphone app (education, self-monitoring, quizzes, messages, social support)
front_details.intervention_group_fragment: African-American adults
front_details.comparator_group_fragment: a delayed-intervention control (no app during control period)

study.title: Comparing Smoking Treatment Programs for Lighter Smokers - 1
study.brief_description: The purpose of this study was to compare two different types of Food and Drug Administration (FDA) approved smoking cessation medications (nicotine patch or bupropion) used in conjunction with two levels of counseling. It was hypothesized that the higher level of counseling would have the highest rates of treatment completion and highest rates of abstinence.

front_details.question: Did bupropion (medication) plus brief counseling (MM) improve treatment completion (taking meds ≥80% of the time and attending required counseling sessions) in lighter smokers receiving bupropion + MM (4 brief 15-min sessions) compared to lighter smokers receiving bupropion + Mayo counseling (10 weekly 30-min sessions) after 52 weeks?
front_details.intervention_fragment: bupropion (medication) plus brief counseling (MM)
front_details.intervention_group_fragment: lighter smokers receiving bupropion + MM (4 brief 15-min sessions)
front_details.outcome_fragment: treatment completion (taking meds ≥80% of the time and attending required counseling sessions)
front_details.comparator_group_fragment: lighter smokers receiving bupropion + Mayo counseling (10 weekly 30-min sessions)

keywords: light smokers, smoking cessation treatment programs

study.title: Nudging Flu Vaccination by Making it Easy for Patients to Schedule a Flu Shot
study.brief_description: The purpose of this study is to test whether messages that make it easy to schedule a flu shot appointment will increase flu shot rates in patients without an upcoming appointment. The study will also test which message versions and message timing are most effective for increasing flu vaccination.

front_details.question: Did sending a simple message that you can get a flu shot at Geisinger (link to self-schedule) improve self-scheduling a flu shot appointment via the patient portal in Active Control (Nov) compared to Passive Control (Nov) after 4 weeks?
front_details.intervention_fragment: sending a simple message that you can get a flu shot at Geisinger (link to self-schedule)
front_details.intervention_group_fragment: Active Control (Nov)
front_details.outcome_fragment: self-scheduling a flu shot appointment via the patient portal

study.title: Tools for Health and Resilience Implemented After Violence Exposure (Project THRIVE)
study.brief_description: Sexual assault victimization is a common and particularly harmful form of trauma that is associated with increased risk for high-risk drinking and other conditions of public health concern, such as PTSD. Given evidence that sexual assault survivors who have low social support or receive negative social reactions to sexual assault disclosure are more likely to experience PTSD and drinking problems, improving social support is a novel target for intervention. The proposed study will attempt to prevent the onset of high-risk drinking and PTSD in sexual assault survivors by developing and testing a web-based early intervention aimed at increasing contact with social supporters and mitigating the harm of negative social reactions; ultimately, results will contribute to advancing the field's understanding of the potential for social support to mitigate the harm of trauma.

front_details.question: Did a 3-week app-based CBT program with daily self-care activities, symptom tracking, and weekly brief coach calls improve alcohol-related problems (Rutgers Alcohol Problem Index–Short Form, RAPI-S score) in women with recent (≤10 weeks) sexual assault who drink and have elevated distress compared to an assessment-only app (daily surveys and symptom tracker) with weekly safety calls after 3 weeks (post-intervention)?
front_details.intervention_fragment: a 3-week app-based CBT program with daily self-care activities, symptom tracking, and weekly brief coach calls
front_details.intervention_group_fragment: women with recent (≤10 weeks) sexual assault who drink and have elevated distress
front_details.outcome_fragment: alcohol-related problems (Rutgers Alcohol Problem Index–Short Form, RAPI-S score)
front_details.comparator_group_fragment: an assessment-only app (daily surveys and symptom tracker) with weekly safety calls

study.title: Adaptive Treatment for Alcohol and Cocaine Dependence
study.brief_description:
1. Primary objective #1: Determine the relative effectiveness of MI-IOP and MI-PC in the full study sample with regard to treatment engagement over weeks 1-12 and cocaine/alcohol use over weeks 1-24.

   * Hypothesis 1: An intervention that explores several possible treatment options with the patient and provides the chosen option (e.g., MI-PC) will produce higher rates of treatment engagement than an intervention focused on engagement in IOP only (e.g., MI-IOP).
   * Hypothesis 2: An intervention that explores several possible treatment options with the patient and provides the chosen option (e.g., MI-PC) will produce better cocaine/alcohol use outcomes than an intervention focused on engagement in IOP only (MI-IOP).
   * Secondary analysis 1: Among the Non-engaged patients, determine rates of selection of each of the three options in MI-PC, retention rates within each option, and cocaine/alcohol use outcomes in each option.
   * Secondary analysis 2: Among the Engaged patients, determine rates of selection of each of the three options in MI-PC, retention rates within each option, and cocaine/alcohol use outcomes in each option.
2. Primary objective #2: Determine whether the relative effectiveness of MI-IOP and MI-PC varies as a function of engagement group, with regard to treatment engagement over weeks 1-12 and cocaine/alcohol use outcomes over weeks 1-24.

   * Hypothesis 1: The predicted main effect on retention favoring MI-PC over MI-IOP will be significantly larger among patients in the Non-engaged group than among those in the Engaged group.
   * Hypothesis 2: The predicted main effect on cocaine/alcohol use outcomes favoring MI-PC over MI-IOP will be significantly larger among patients in the Non-engaged group than among those in the Engaged group.

front_details.question: Did motivational interviewing with patient choice (MI-PC) improve treatment engagement (number of sessions attended) in MI-PC non-engaged at 2 weeks compared to MI-IOP non-engaged at 2 weeks after weeks 3–12?
front_details.intervention_fragment: motivational interviewing with patient choice (MI-PC)
front_details.intervention_group_fragment: MI-PC non-engaged at 2 weeks

study.title: Fertility Decision-Making in Youth and Young Adults
study.brief_description: The aim of this study is to test if using a web-based medical decision-making tool on the topics of fertility and fertility-preservation increases knowledge among transgender youth and young adults.

front_details.question: Did using a web-based fertility decision aid improve fertility knowledge (percent correct on a 41-item test) in transgender adolescents and young adults compared to before use (pre-test) after immediate post-test (same day)?
front_details.intervention_fragment: using a web-based fertility decision aid
front_details.intervention_group_fragment: transgender adolescents and young adults
front_details.outcome_fragment: fertility knowledge (percent correct on a 41-item test)
